abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Food and Drugs Capacity
            Building Project for India were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) when
            starting a reform program in a difficult area such as
            improvement in food and drug quality and safety, it is
            prudent to be less ambitious in what can be achieved in the
            first operation and to build capacity for implementing
            reforms over the long term; 2) capacity building for complex
            regulatory functions needs a well coordinated approach. To
            achieve a significant increase in quality and quantity of
            lab tests for example, it is not sufficient to build a new
            lab, hire lab staff and procure equipment. At the same time,
            the number of inspectors who collect samples in the field
            also needs to be increased to provide the additional samples
            and make use of the increased lab capacity; 3) prior to
            launching the project, the administrative steps necessary
            and time requirements for creating positions and recruiting
            public servants could have been investigated and addressed
            proactively on a high level in order to avoid the delays in
            creating and filling positions encountered during
            implementation; 4) procurement of simple office equipment
            and standard lab equipment could be done better locally in
            states, possibly under a framework contract that provides
            favorable terms and prices; 5) delivery of new equipment,
            installation, validation, and application training need to
            be closely supervised by the procuring unit in order to
            ensure the full functioning of specialized equipment; and 6)
            the onus of obtaining utility connections (electricity and
            water) for the facility could be built into the contract to
            avoid delay in making the facility functional before the
            defect liability period.
